results.title: Two laws. Part 1. Police times
results.creator_credit: Alessandro Cavadini, Carolyn Strachan and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: Part 1 of a 4-part innovative film entitled “Two laws” which deals with the Borroloola people’s struggle for the recognition of their law. This part looks at Borroloola in the 1930’s, dramatically reconstructing a conflict there between First Nations people, new white settlers and police in 1933. The other parts of the film are: “Welfare times”, “Struggle for our land” and “Living with two laws”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alessandro Cavadini, Carolyn Strachan and Australian Film Commission

results.title: Two laws. Part 3: Struggle for our land
results.creator_credit: Alessandro Cavadini, Carolyn Strachan and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: Part 3 of a 4-part innovative film entitled “Two laws” which deals with the Borroloola people’s struggle for the recognition of their law. Describes attachment to land, conflict over sacred sites, the 1977 Borroloola land claim and the bargaining strategy of the people with the government, the cattle stations and the mining company. The other parts of the film are “Police times”, “Welfare times”, “Living with two laws”. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Dugong! Dugong!
results.creator_credit: Australian Museum, Howard Hughes and New South Wales Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Commencing with the telling of a legend about the dugong, the film then shows the hunting, killing and cooking of the dugong by the First Nations people living on Mornington Island. Hunting is now done by motor boat as opposed to the traditional method using nets, which is re-enacted.

results.title: Stone age technology
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Quantum”.
In this short segment from Quantum, we are shown the unique stone-age technology of quartz cutting, developed by Australian First Nations people some 20,000 years ago. The technique for cutting quartz is quite different and more sophisticated than that used for flint and had to be invented here, although it was a skill later discarded.

results.title: Sick at heart
results.creator_credit: Debbie Whitmont and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
The appalling statistics on the health of First Nations peoples in Australia - a male life expectancy less than that of Bangladesh, the highest risk of death by murder in the world, are a disgrace to Australia, and whilst there are those who care, there seems to be little hope for the future as many despair of any easy solution. Paul Barry and the Four Corners team table this generally pessimistic report.

results.title: Black sickness, black cure
results.creator_credit: Jonathan Holmes and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
The statistics on Australia’s First Nations peoples’ health are notoriously bad, including high rates of alcoholism, infant mortality and leprosy, a disease which has almost disappeared from the western world. The program looks at ways First Nations people are beginning to take control of their own health services, ultimately hoping to combine western medicine with their own bush in a holistic approach to the issue of health. Chris Masters reports on some of the initiatives, successful and unsuccessful, to blend the two.

results.title: A Shame Like Alice. Part 2
results.creator_credit: Leonard Lee, SBS-TV and Lee Gordon Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Focus”.

In March 1983 Focus spent one week in the Northern Territory looking at the living conditions of First Nations people in the most famous small town in Australia, Alice Springs. Includes interviews with Neville Bonner and Al Grassby.

results.title: Bound for Botany Bay
results.creator_credit: John Dollar, Jonathan King and First Fleet Films
results.brief_description: Using re-enactments and contemporary paintings and documents, this program addresses crime and punishment in 18th Century England, reasons for the colonisation of Australia, the fitting and sailing of the First Fleet and the arrival at Botany Bay and Port Jackson. It includes a re-enactment of this arrival performed in modern Sydney, includes First Nations people protesting about the loss of their land rights. Suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.

results.description: Using re-enactments and contemporary paintings and documents, this program addresses crime and punishment in 18th Century England, reasons for the colonisation of Australia, the fitting and sailing of the First Fleet and the arrival at Botany Bay and Port Jackson. results.title: Special treatment: locking up aboriginal children
results.creator_credit: Margaret Anne Smith and Smith Street Films
results.brief_description:
A documentary exploring the incarceration of First Nations youth in the context of the history of the Stolen Generations, the ongoing racist targeting by police, and an institutionally racist justice system.
Features prominent commentators such as Lyall Munro Jnr., Evelyn Crawford and Shane Phillips, as well as criminologist Chris Cunneen.
